title: For Sale/Trade:  Taurus PT 24/7 Pro in .45
postcontent:
The 24/7 pistol features an injection molded polymer frame with blued carbon steel, stainless steel, or titanium slides. The PT 24/7 pistols share several safety innovations with other Taurus product lines, including a positive firing pin block as well as the 'Taurus Safety Latch', a transfer bar safety which prevents firing of the pistol unless the trigger is pulled. Together these safeties assure that the pistol will not fire if it is accidentally dropped.  All 24/7 models also include a frame-mounted manual safety lever, and are equipped with an integrated firearm locking safety system, which Taurus calls the ‘Taurus Security System' (TSS). 24/7 pistols are also equipped with a visible/tactile loaded chamber indicator and a dust cover Picatinny accessory rail integration system, allowing for the attachment of accessories such as laser sights or tactical lights. Heinie ‘Straight Eight’ combat sights are for the Pro Handling characteristics of 24/7 pistols are enhanced by features such as an ambidextrous decocking lever and ergonometric design attributes which Taurus calls 'Memory pads', consisting of various grooves which promote proper consistent hand placement for superior handling control.  In addition, a secure grasp of the pistol grip is afforded by a high adhesion gripping surface. An option standard on Pro models is a soft, ribbed, non-slip, hand-conforming grip which Taurus dubbed the ‘Ribber’.

Trigger actions

Pro models sport single action/double action triggers. This system differs from most dual action triggers in that the initial pull is single action with the double action coming into play only on a misfire. Most dual action triggers are double action on the initial shot with subsequent shots being single action. This system allows for two major advantages, one being that the initial trigger pull is light and crisp, therefore more controllable, and the second being that if a round misfires, the trigger can be quickly pulled again in double action mode, repeating the attempt to fire the recalcitrant round. This type of SA/DA system, pioneered on Taurus pistols, is much faster and simpler than the standard tap, rack, bang method of clearing a dud cartridge.

title: For Sale:  Colt 1911 .45 $1699obo Serial:512xxx Made in 1918, not a 1911A1
postcontent:
Asking 1699 obo.
A genuine Colt's Manufacturing Company .45 Caliber
Its a blued 1911, with a 6 digit serial number 512xxx manufactured in 1918, and is my understanding it would have been a USN/USMC weapon. With the later A1 modifications it would have been used in the Marine Corp, as it is my understanding its was the Marine Corp that had the A1 mods done to the original 1911s.

Being sold as is, where is, without warranty expressed or implied...blah blah blah, you either know what you are buying, and understand the nature and condition of something like this or maybe collecting antique weapons is not for you. ;-)

Labeling reads as follows:
(holding as if shooting)

*Right side on Slide
"MODEL OF 1911 U.S.ARMY"

* Right side on Frame
"No 512xxx"    (This puts the manufacture date in 1918 near the end of a batch of 347,000 made that year. by far the largest single year production run ever)

*Left side on Slide
"PATENTED APR. 20, 1897. SEPT. 9, 1902.
DEC. 19, 1905. FEB. 14, 1911. AUG. 19, 1913."

Reading from the barrel exit back left to right the above two lines are followed by the Colt horse logo, which is a Rampant Colt—The original logo of Colt's Firearms, (a colt up on its hind legs with an arrow and bow).
After the Rampant Colt continuing back are two more lines of text:

"COLT"S PT FA MFG. CO.
HARTFORD, CT U.S.A."

*Left side on Frame forward of trigger guard and slide release hole
"UNITED STATES PROPERTY"

Just behind the trigger and just above the magazine release is the inspectors stamp.
This is either "S18", "SIB" or "SI8" with a small graphic of an eagle head above it.

INSIDE:
*Underside of barrel near the back before it tapers up there is a "G" (which I think stands for Government contract Order.
*On the slide itself, on the rear section that has the firing pin within it, there is an "S" that is contained with a circle just large enough to contain. Also stamped on that section are some hash mark that look like measurement, a number "4" is stamped in the middle.

It has what is referred to as a Type 3 hammer.

The wood grips have the finely engraved checkering pattern with large smooth diamond shapes where the screws go in.


What I have been told. 
While it is indeed a 1911 it has some of the modifications for a 1911A1 such as the shoe on the rear of the grip.
It has the shorter trigger, but you can tell its a 1911 because it lacks the tapered cutouts in the frame behind the trigger. It has the longer spur on the hammer. It also has the original grip checkering with the smooth diamond cuts at the screws as opposed to the simplified grip checkering.

Overall condition is:
Fully functional.
Complete.
Finish has most of the original bluing with a little surface oxidation, and a couple small spots of pitting.
Ready to be professionally refinished or restored.

Asking 1599 obo

Also willing to trade for a high end .45 like an Ed Brown, Les Baer or Wilson. Other trades might be both a Sig 556 and Kimber, also after a Remington 1187, stainless Mini-14 and a short barrel stainless .357 or a combination plus cash.


Technically speaking this is NOT a gun, but rather a Curio and Relic, and is there for not considered a "Firearm" by definition. I suspect that means it can't be banned.
